cards.front: State the linearity property of the FS.
cards.back: αx(t) + βy(t) ↔ αX_k + βY_k, provided x(t) and y(t) have the SAME fundamental frequency ω₀.

cards.front: State the time shifting property of the FS.
State the time reversal property of the FS.
cards.back:
x(−t) ↔ X_{−k}

The coefficients mirror about k = 0. For real signals: X_{−k} = X_k*, so time reversal gives conjugate coefficients.

cards.front: State the time scaling property of the FS.
cards.back: x(αt) has period T₀/α and fundamental frequency αω₀, but the FS coefficients X_k remain unchanged. Only the frequency grid is rescaled.
The time shift factor e^{−jkω₀t₀} has magnitude 1. Multiplying X_k by a unit-magnitude complex number rotates it in the complex plane without changing its length → magnitudes unchanged.

cards.front: Why does higher k mean more phase change under time shifting?
cards.back: Higher k = higher frequency = shorter period. The same time delay t₀ represents more cycles at higher frequencies, so the phase shift −kω₀t₀ grows linearly with k.
When x(t) and y(t) have DIFFERENT fundamental frequencies. The harmonic grids (kω₀ vs kω₀') don't align, so you can't add X_k and Y_k at the same index k.

cards.front: How do you use properties to avoid re-integration?
cards.back: Start with a known FS pair (e.g., square pulse). Apply properties (shift, reverse, scale, linearity) to derive the FS of the modified signal without evaluating any new integrals.

cards.front: What is the FS of x(t − T₀/4) in terms of X_k?
cards.back:
X_k · e^{−jkω₀T₀/4} = X_k · e^{−jkπ/2}

For k=1: phase −π/2; k=2: phase −π; k=3: phase −3π/2; etc.

cards.front: Summarise what changes vs stays the same under time shift.
cards.back:
UNCHANGED: |X_k| (magnitude), signal shape, power
CHANGED: ∠X_k (phase shifts by −kω₀t₀), signal position in time
